awd_titl_txt: Funding to support Operations and Maintenance of the Monterey Accelerated Research System (MARS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Funding is provided to continue operations and maintence of the Maintenance of the Monterey Accelerated Research System (MARS). The MARS cabled observatory provides a deep-water facility for testing and development and is a compelling solution for many ocean science experiments. MBARI has integrated the MARS Observatory into the Monterey Bay Aquarium 'Discovering Monterey Canyon' auditorium program as well as in the new MBARI exhibit. The Monterey Bay Aquarium has over one million visitors a year, thereby providing wide exposure for MARS and OOI to the public. The EARTH Project, a science teacher outreach effort, has used MARS as a tool at over 20 presentations to high school educators.  

The Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) installed a cabled test bed and has been operating the Monterey Accelerated Research System (MARS) since MARS became operational November 10, 2008. The purpose of this proposal is to provide continued funding for operations and maintenance costs of MARS.

por.por_cntn:
The Monterey Accelerated Research System (MARS) is an undersea cabled observatory consisting of 52-km (32-mile) undersea cable that carries data and power to a science node 891 meters (2,923 feet) below the surface of Monterey Bay. The science node allows connection of up to eight science experiments at any given time.  Using a ship with a Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV), science experiments can be periodically changed by way of wet mate connectors on the science node.  MARS entered operation in 2007, providing ocean scientists with 24-hour-a-day access to instruments and experiments in the deep sea.

Over this Award period numerous instruments have been connected to MARS representing; technology development, trials for transition to larger cabled observatories, time series measurements, public engagement/education, and STEM training. Some the instruments include:

Ocean Soundscape - Hydrophones record sounds that originate from living organisms, natural processes and human activities. The project is a collaboration between MBARI and Naval Post Graduate School, using both a traditional hydrophone and a directional hydrophone.  Data from this project is shared in real time with the public through the project's website.

Deep Echo-Integrating Marine Observatory System (DEIMOS), an upward looking fisheries sonar system can monitor the entire water column in real time. Data from DEIMOS is helping researchers understand how animals in the open ocean respond to tides, cycles of light and darkness, upwelling, storms, and even long-term processes such as El Nino events.

Monterey Ocean-Bottom Broadband Seismometer (MOBB), a cabled seismometer which is provided power and real time data access from MARS. 

Geodetic and Seismic Sensor Module - in situ seafloor pressure calibration to eliminate pressure sensor drift.

Distributed Acoustic Sensing (DAS), Distributed fiber-optic sensing technology coupled to existing subsea cables (dark fiber) allows observation of ocean and solid earth phenomena.  This initial experiment used an optical fiber from the MARS system during a 4-day maintenance period with a distributed acoustic sensing (DAS) instrument operating onshore, creating a ~10,000-component, 20-kilometer-long seismic array. A minor earthquake occurred during the experiment period, and recordings of the wave field identified multiple submarine fault zones.

Quest Educational Platform; a multi-faceted system that incorporated an ROV, a pan and tilt camera system and a hydrophone. The system was designed to give deep ocean access to high school programs and develop lesson plans for the enhancement of Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education programs. 

The science node is due for a technology upgrade after 15 years of operations.  During this award period progress was made on the design of a temporary node that will provide four science ports during the upgrade process of 12-18 months.  The technology upgrade of the science node, will ensure the continued viability of the MARS system to support ocean sciences for many years to come.

MARS science node's close proximity to MBARI's homeport of Moss Landing CA allows same day access by ships and ROVs for maintenance or exchanges of science experiments connected to the node.  This geographic proximity to ships and ROVs is essential to a testbed system, unlike larger cabled observatories that only have one limited duration annual cruise.  The previous examples of sensors and experiments supported by MARS, demonstrates that the system continues to meet its initial goal of providing a cost-effective platform providing persistent real time presence on the seafloor using high bandwidth and electrical power.   

The project is operated by the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (MBARI) and funded by the National Science Foundation (NSF).   Additional information on MARS can be found at https://www.mbari.org/at-sea/cabled-observatory/ .


Last Modified: 07/06/2022
Modified by: Michael G Kelly
